Thanks Todd,
I currently use POI to read and write files.   A friend said try not to use
Files as puts a dependency on the files system.
 
So started putting the contents of small files as constants of a String
variable.  However for bigger files/non-test files like Excel think need to
actually pull in a file.
 
So my question was how and where do people generally put there data files.
I know we can read them via getSystemResourceAsStream() etc.  Just trying to
see how generally done, e.g. our tests placed in same file, are properties
place din a properties file with each test etc.
 
Currently run my tests though Inteli J.
 
Generally at work the main developers just have a file named test.properties
in each test folder and they read the parameters from there, but on
reflection think that gives a dependency on the file system for properties,
which should probably be in the test.  For data files it makes sense,
although I also like the idea of having a data folder for this.
 
Anyone got an example of a JUnit testcase which uses files?  Just would like
to see it done elsewhere, as think not totally done correct where I
work.....
 
Thanks,
Darren

> Spoke to a friend who said you should not have properties in 
> a properties file as gives dependence on files for test cases 
> (makes good sense).

You've got to inject your dependencies somehow. We use Java properties
to do that (for the purposes of test) where I work.

> Are there any classes (out of the box I am not aware of) for 
> reading properties files in the current test case and other 
> files like Excel?

For the first part, why don't you just load the properties file into the
JVM and then get the properties through the regular old Java System
object?

For the second part, maybe I don't understand the question, but to read
Excel files into a Java test case, I think POI-HSSF is the way to go
(http://jakarta. <http://jakarta.apache.org/poi/hssf/index.html>
apache.org/poi/hssf/index.html). But you already
mentioned POI, so maybe you already know that...

Todd.
